verses.text: O LORD, my heart is not proud, nor my eyes lifted up high. I do not concern myself with things too great or too wonderful for me.
verses.comment: The verse reflects a humble approach before God, rejecting pride and self-exaltation. The phrase 'things too great or too wonderful for me' is a Hebrew idiom implying submission and trust in the divine mysteries—a prelude to spiritual maturity and obedience (see Job 42:3; Prov. 30:32). This humility echoes Christ's own humility (see Philippians 2:5-8), inviting believers to imitate His example.

verses.text: Instead, I have calmed and quieted my soul, like a weaned child with its mother; like a weaned child is my soul within me.
verses.comment: The image of a 'weaned child' expresses serene trust and deep rest in God's presence, moving beyond the anxieties of self-will. This image is drawn on elsewhere (Isaiah 66:13), depicting God’s nurturing care. In the New Testament, Jesus uses the image of a child as the model for entering the Kingdom (Matthew 18:3-4), affirming the value of dependent trust and spiritual littleness. The spiritual tradition sees this as a call to detachment from the world and deeper spiritual communion.

verses.text: O Israel, hope in the LORD from now and forevermore.
verses.comment: The psalmist exhorts the whole people to entrust themselves to God perpetually. Like verse 3 of Psalm 130, hope is anchored in the Lord’s covenantal faithfulness and mercy. Spiritually, this is an invitation to persevere in faith, looking ahead to the promises fulfilled in Christ (see Ps. 130:7, 1 Peter 1:13), and recognizing the necessity of ongoing hope grounded in God’s unchanging love, which is often mediated through the community and sacraments.
